question_details.title: Will Iran announce an evacuation of Tehran before 2026?
question_details.description:
Iran has debated decanting political/administrative functions from Tehran for decades, citing seismic risk, extreme water stress, land subsidence, pollution, and over-centralization. A year ago, President Masoud Pezeshkian [ordered a formal study of relocation](https://www.intellinews.com/iran-president-backs-moving-capital-from-tehran-to-persian-gulf-354450/?utm_source=chatgpt.com), reviving earlier proposals dating back at least to 2009.

In January 2025, the government [stated that](https://www.iranintl.com/en/202501077205) Iran “will relocate its capital to the southern coastal region of Makran,” as a response to Tehran’s overpopulation, power shortages, and water scarcity. Throughout 2025, [the environmental case strengthened](https://www.ft.com/content/c9ec6008-ed62-40ab-86eb-109d47c02d7e) as Tehran faces some of the world’s highest land-subsidence rates due to over-pumped aquifers.

President Pezeshkian has continued arguing that Iran “must” move the capital, pointing to the water crisis. He has now said that should there be no rain by Azar (21st of November in the Persian calendar) the government would have to ration water and then [potentially evacuate Tehran](https://www.lemonde.fr/en/environment/article/2025/11/14/iran-faces-its-worst-drought-in-six-decades-considers-evacuating-tehran_6747437_114.html) if the situation continued further.

**Iran's Water Crisis Sparks Government Pushback After President's Evacuation Warning**
Iran is facing its worst water crisis in decades, with Tehran's water reservoirs dropping below 5% of capacity and over 10 million residents experiencing frequent water cuts. President Masoud Pezeshkian warned in November 2024 that Tehran might need to be evacuated if rainfall does not occur by December, sparking public panic. She emphasized that the government has 'serious plans' to address the crisis, including cloud seeding using silver iodide, water rationing, and water transfers from other sources. The crisis stems from six consecutive years of drought, climate change, inefficient agricultural water use (accounting for 90% of national consumption), illegal well drilling, over-extraction of groundwater causing land subsidence at 300 mm/year (60 times the critical threshold), and damage from the 12-day Israel-Iran conflict in summer 2024. Tehran recorded only 2.3 mm of rainfall by early November 2024, an 81% drop from the historical average. Key reservoirs like Latian and Amir Kabir have dropped below 14 million cubic meters from a previous capacity of 500 million. The crisis has spread nationwide, with reservoir levels in West and East Azerbaijan provinces falling to single-digit percentages, and economic and political instability fears intensifying amid international sanctions. **Iran on the Brink of a Nervous Crisis: Water, Energy, and Existential Stress**
Iran is facing a deepening crisis marked by water scarcity, energy shortages, and environmental degradation. In 2024–2025, Iran achieved a historic record by purchasing nearly 12 million tons of wheat from domestic farmers under its guaranteed purchase program, nearly securing self-sufficiency in cereals. However, much of the agricultural sector remains focused on water-intensive crops like pistachios, primarily for export, accelerating groundwater depletion and increasing vulnerability to shortages. Rice, a dietary staple, is heavily imported—mostly from India, which supplies over four-fifths of annual needs—while animal feed maize is mainly sourced from Brazil. Contaminated water and land subsidence are worsening, with studies from Tehran’s water and sanitation company (Abfa) and the Iranian Water Research Institute showing a 60–70 cm drop in groundwater levels in Shahriyar, linked to over-pumping and soil deformation. In July 2025, a record heatwave exceeding 50°C in southwestern cities caused unprecedented electricity demand, straining an aging grid due to austerity-driven underinvestment. As a result, daily power outages—lasting up to four hours—have become routine in Tehran and 28 other cities, disrupting households, businesses, and public services. Citizens report dire conditions: residents struggle to access clean water, face blocked elevators, and carry water manually. Social media posts highlight the suffering of students and caregivers. In response, proposals to relocate the capital to Mokran on the southeastern coast have resurfaced in early 2025, though no decision has been made. Supporters cite pollution, subsidence, and water shortages in Tehran; opponents argue the plan is unrealistic and costly, advocating instead for modernization of the current capital. The crisis reflects the cumulative impact of past political choices, climate constraints, international sanctions, regional tensions, and the real threat of military escalation. For many Iranians, this daily hardship fuels a profound sense of injustice and despair over a future without hope.

**Iran Seeks Alternatives to Evacuating Tehran Amid Historic Drought Period**
Iran's government has dismissed the idea of evacuating Tehran, deeming it impractical, despite President Masoud Pezeshkian's earlier warning that water rationing may be necessary by December and evacuation might be required if no rainfall occurs. According to Iran's National Meteorological Prediction Center, Tehran has experienced a 95.8% drop in precipitation compared to historical averages, with major reservoirs below 5% capacity and rainfall at record lows since records began. The capital, home to approximately 18 million people—far exceeding the estimated sustainable population of 5 million—faces its sixth consecutive year of drought, the longest such period in 60 years. Portavoz Fatemeh Mohajerani clarified that Pezeshkian's statements were a 'responsible warning' and emphasized that the government has long warned against overpopulation in Tehran. Despite limited rainfall in the west and north of the country over the weekend, Tehran has not seen precipitation since last spring.

**Iran launches first cloud seeding of water year amid worst drought in decades**
Iran conducted its first cloud seeding operation of the 2025–26 water year on November 16 over the Urmia Lake basin, as the country faces its sixth consecutive year of drought. According to Mohammad Mehdi Javadianzadeh, head of the Organisation for Development and Utilization of Modern Meteoric Water Technologies, renewable water resources have declined from an annual average of 128 billion cubic metres two decades ago to about 80 billion cubic metres today. Nationwide dams are nearly empty, and over 90% of water is consumed by agriculture, much through inefficient irrigation, accelerating groundwater depletion and land subsidence. Authorities warn that without significant rainfall, Tehran could face water rationing and, in extreme cases, evacuation. The cloud seeding project will run until mid-May 2026, using aircraft and drones in favorable precipitation systems. Javadianzadeh stated, 'We are trying to carry out the operation on all systems entering the country that are favourable for fertilisation,' with missions over Tehran Province pending confirmation of conditions. The technique involves injecting silver iodide or potassium iodide into clouds to stimulate precipitation. Satellite and local reports indicated rainfall in northwestern provinces on November 15 and snowfall at a northern Tehran ski resort—the first this year. Meteorologists reported that autumn rainfall was down by approximately 89% compared to long-term averages, marking the driest period in 50 years. Officials are also planning penalties for households and businesses exceeding water quotas. Ahmad Vezifeh, head of Iran’s National Crisis and Drought Management Centre, described reservoir levels in Tehran, West Azerbaijan, East Azerbaijan, and Central provinces as 'critical,' with capacities reduced to just a few percent. Public concern has risen, with hundreds gathering in Tehran and other cities to pray for rain. The drought has worsened electricity shortages, increasing reliance on fossil-fuel power plants as hydropower output declines. During summer, government offices in Tehran and other cities have periodically closed to conserve energy, sparking complaints from businesses over lost revenue.
